InformationGroup.LoginFailed: Login failed! Check your username and password!
InformationGroup.UserCreateFailure: User registration failed! Make sure you're connected to internet and only make a password with those character: A-Z, a-z, 1-9
InformationGroup.WelcomeGate: Welcome to the campus of the faculty of applied sciences
InformationGroup.AppDesc: Selaru VR is an application that contains VR Tour and VR Light Fire Training to support the knowledge needs of a building, especially the Faculty of Applied Sciences at Telkom University.
InformationGroup.BasicInfo1: Every office, especially an office with a high-rise building type, must have a fire prevention and control management program.
InformationGroup.BasicInfo2: In addition to these efforts, the management of evacuation accessibility is also important to speed up the evacuation process that minimize the number of victims.
InformationGroup.BasicInfo3: There are 3 causes of fires that can occur and will get bigger, namely: (1) Presence of flammable fuel or materials (2) The presence of a lighter source (3) The presence of oxygen in the air which functions to support combustion (ILO, 2018)
InformationGroup.BasicInfo4: The ability to manage and reduce risks related to these 3 things will be an effective step in reducing the possibility of more severe fire.
InformationGroup.BasicInfo5: One of these capabilities is the ability to quickly detect fires and the ability to control fires and extinguish them.
InformationGroup.JenisAparSub: *Click on the buttons below to show the information
InformationGroup.JenisAparAir: Estinguisher types of liquid (water) use a red color code on the tube. This type of fire extinguisher should not be used for fires involving flammable liquids and gases, live electrical installations / equipment, and flammable metals
InformationGroup.JenisAparFoam: Foam type fire extinguishers use a cream color code on the tube. This type of fire extinguisher should not be used in types of fires involving voltage electrical installations / equipment and flammable metals.
InformationGroup.JenisAparPowder: Foam type fire extinguishers use a blue color code on the tube. This type of fire extinguisher is not intended for types of fires involving installation of connections and flammable metals.
InformationGroup.JenisAparCo2: These fire extinguishers are used to extinguish Class B fires, which are flammable liquids, and are excellent for extinguishing fires involving a large number of electrical installations / equipment.
InformationGroup.JenisAparWet: Wet chemical fire extinguishers use a yellow color code on the tube. This type of fire extinguisher is not recommended for use in types of fires involving electrical equipment in operation, flammable liquids, and flammable metals.
InformationGroup.ToolsApar: Light Fire Extinguisher (APAR), a tool that is light and can easily be used by one person in an effort to extinguish a fire at the start of the fire
InformationGroup.ToolsAlarm: Fire alarm system, is a tool for notifying fire at an initial level which includes a manual fire alarm and / or an automatic fire alarm
InformationGroup.ToolsHydrant: Courtyard hydrant, namely hydrant outside the building
InformationGroup.ToolsSprinkler: Automatic sprinkler system, which is a fire extinguisher installation permanently installed to protect the building from fire hazards which will work automatically to emit water, if the appliance is exposed to heat at a certain temperature
InformationGroup.ToolsVentilasi: Smoke control system, namely a natural or mechanical system that functions to emit smoke
InformationGroup.KelasAparA: Class A ─ Fires containing solid materials except metal, such as wood, paper, plastic, rubber and textiles.
InformationGroup.KelasAparB: Class B ─ Fires involving flammable liquid materials, such as gasoline, petroleum, tar, oil, oil-based paints, solvents, etc. (which cannot mix with water).
InformationGroup.KelasAparC: Class C ─ Fires involving live electrical installations or equipment.
InformationGroup.KelasAparD: Class D ─ Fire in flammable metals, such as magnesium, titanium, zirconium, sodium, lithium and potassium.
InformationGroup.KelasAparK: Class K ─ Fires involving combustible cooking media, such as cooking oil and fat (animal and vegetable fats).
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide1: If the cause of the fire is very mild, extinguish the small fire with a damp cloth.
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide2: If the fire is not controlled with a wet cloth, go to the nearest fire extinguisher panel and take it to the fire site
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide3: Notify security and inform the location of the fire.
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide4: Try to put out the fire using the fire extinguisher properly. (Note: fire hoses should only be used by firefighters).
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide5: If it cannot be extinguished, close all doors leading to the fire site, notify security of the situation and initiate evacuation procedures.
InformationGroup.HandlingSlide6: Do not use the elevator and explain the situation when firefighters arrive.
InformationGroup.HowTo2: Pull/Remove APAR lever locking pin / Extinguisher Tube.
InformationGroup.HowTo3: Aim the hose at the center of the fire.
InformationGroup.HowTo4: Press the lever to remove the contents of the APAR / Extinguisher Tube.
InformationGroup.HowTo5: Apply evenly until the fire goes out.

LevelGroup.Level0_Desc: Knowing the condition of the kitchen that you will use is the main requirement in cooking activities.
LevelGroup.Level1_Desc: Grilling is the technique of cooking foods over live fire over direct heat.
LevelGroup.Level2_Desc: Steaming is gently cooks the food with flow of hot air.
LevelGroup.Level3_Desc: Searing refers to the browning of food – usually pertaining to meat or fish – in a pan over high heat.
LevelGroup.Level4_Desc: In a frying the food is cut into similarly sized bite-sized pieces and cook with a small amount of oil.
LevelGroup.Level5_Desc: This term is used in conjunction with meat, in particular cuts of meat that benefit from long, slow cooking to become tender.
